summary: Since the last book is to be titled "A Dream of Spring" does that mean we will never get an actual epilogue in spring? Will the...
question: Since the last book is to be titled "A Dream of Spring" does that mean we will never get an actual epilogue in spring? Will the battle of the dawn revert/shorten Winter or will we end in a bittersweet (forgive overused term) winter day where everything is a possibility and the dream is almost tangible? Personally, what do you think will be the bulk of the epilogue (scenes? dialogue? self-reflection?) and who would be the best PoV for it? thank you :)
answer: Don’t know about most of it! The only thing I’m pretty sure of is that Bran’s the best PoV for an epilogue.

summary: Now that Sansa is left with Bran as the only other family member at Winterfell, I hope the show gives them scenes together and...
question: Now that Sansa is left with Bran as the only other family member at Winterfell, I hope the show gives them scenes together and he maybe shows more of his old self around her? I love them both and this relationship deserves more screentime. If Sansa has to rule with anyone else it should be Bran, NOT Jon who is bound to argue with her constantly while dismissing her intelligence and opinions.
answer: They have to give us a Sansa and Bran scene. It’s getting ridiculous now, she hasn’t had one with him since ep 4 of season 7 and that was mostly her watching Arya and Bran reuniting. Also yes! Sansa and Bran would easily work better as a team than Sansa and Jon

summary: Was talking to a friend who is a hardcore Dany stan and Sansa hater about who would end up on the throne and I suggested Bran...
question: Was talking to a friend who is a hardcore Dany stan and Sansa hater about who would end up on the throne and I suggested Bran and she literally said the words,” He has no legs”. Like wtf. Wtf?!
answer: The ableism Bran Stark gets from the fandom is sickening. I hope that person stays mad when Bran outlives the demon they stan

title: Family - Sansa Stark
body:
It had been a long while since there had been a servant of House Stark in Winterfell; let alone a true born Stark. Upon the return of Ned Stark’s eldest daughter, new life floods the old castle. Shared memories resurface and forgotten feelings arise once more. Perhaps there is hope for this broken, scattered family after all.

It was a sign, a message from the Old Gods that the tides of fortune were shifting. It had to be. The small flakes that fell from the grey skies filled you with a sense of hope; one that, despite the horror surrounding you, could not be snuffed out. Finally, you thought, the fates would fall in the favor of House Stark once more. 

Days after the first signs of the coming winter started to lazily float down from the clouds, a more vivid display of change walked through the gates of Winterfell. It strode in, carried on the shoulders of a strong young woman with flowing red locks. Sansa Stark, Lady Stark now, had finally returned. Alongside her half-brother, Jon Snow. While her homecoming spark much join amongst those in the North, you couldn’t help but feel that undying bud of hope wither slightly.

For while Sansa Stark was a source of new hope, she was a source of bittersweet feelings for you. Having grown up along the Stark siblings, you formed a tight connection with the girl; one that was not shared in the way you longed for it to be. Dreams of holding her fell short when she talked about how she fancied the dear Prince Joffrey.

Time had passed now, and perhaps her heart had changed along with it. You wished that the glimmer of hope you held applied to that as well as you walked up to the main castle gates. The two guards stationed there looked you up and down, glaring at you stepped forwards.

“I’m Y/N L/N, my family has been serving the member of House Stark for centuries. I am here to take up my position as handmaiden to the Lady of the House.” One of the guards scoffed at your words, shaking his head at the other.

“Look here, peasant, Lady Stark gave us strict orders to-”

“Let my family enter without questioning. Yet it seems you have failed to complete this task.” Shocked and wide-eyed, the guard turned to face Sansa. She stood stoically, a dark furred cloak graced her slim shoulders. Familiarly piercing blue eyes stared daggers into the bumbling men before you. With a slight smile on your lips you stepped past the guards as they apologized for the inconvenience.

“Y/N,” Sansa said, her gaze softening as it shifted to you, “it has been too long.”

“Indeed it has, my Lady.”

“Sansa. You may always call me Sansa.” She waved off your formalities, lifting you from your bowing posture as a true leader would. Heat rose to your cheeks as you met her icy stare once more. She had changed, something deep within her had shifted, but she was still as bossy as she had been in your youth.

“I’ve missed you, Sansa,” you said, straightening your back. “I dreamed of the day you would return.”

“As did I,” Sansa replied, a sigh escaping her lips as she spoke. She glanced around the stone-brick walls of her home, as if comparing it to the memory she had so dearly clung to in King’s Landing. “Come now, I’ve taken up my Lord Father and Lady Mother’s chambers. There is much to sift through and clean.”

The walk through the silent halls of Winterfell was just that; deathly quiet. Even with the new vigor felt by the Northerns on their leader’s heirs return, the halls of their home were still with loss. As you followed Sansa, you passed doorways to old rooms. One was Robb’s, the boy King who treated you with kindness when you talked of Sansa. Another to the right was Rickon’s. The poor boy never stood a chance against the harsh world around him. Then Bran’s room, then Arya’s, both empty and devoid of life.

“I think about them, always,” Sansa murmurs as she unlocks the door to the chambers that her parents once lived in. “I see them in my dreams. Happy and alive.”

“There are ways to be happy again, Sansa.” You rest a hand on her cloaked shoulder and the girl turns her Tully blue eyes to you. She studies your face a moment longer before pushing the door before her open.

“Perhaps….”

At soon as the door opened, you both strode inside. A flood of warm memories rushed back to you. Ned Stark and Catelyn, raising their children, happy to raise you alongside them. You remember washing their fur blankets, being distracted by Sansa’s singing in the distance. Then the Boltons. They burned those same blankets, just as they scorched the fields of the North. You remembered running for your life after your family had been killed.

An alliance towards the Starks under the cruel rule of House Bolton was a death sentence. You had no choice but to leave your home behind. As much as it had pained you then, you were glad you did. If you hadn’t, you wouldn’t have been reunited with Sansa.

“Do you remember the day that Rickon was born?” You turned at Sansa’s question, brows furrowed slightly.

“Of course,” you replied, watching as she sat on her parent’s old bed. “You were so worried by your mother’s cries that you had me take you to the Godswood to pray.”

“Yes, and I had you pray beside me.” You nodded at the memory. “Did you pray?”

“What do you mean?”

“When my family was being torn apart by the lions, did you pray?” Her words hung in the air between you. Such sadness fell from her words and your heart broke.

“I did, Sansa. Every night I would pray that Robb would win each battle he fought. I prayed that we would find Arya. I prayed that I would see you once more before the life left my eyes forever. It seems the Gods have answered my prayers, for here you are.” You moved as you spoke, standing in front of Sansa. In a fit of passion you ran your fingers through the strands of auburn hair that fell around her face.

“I gave up praying,” Sansa whispered, “but when I did I wished for you to save me. Not my mother, not my father’s loyal men, not even Robb. Just you. I wanted…”

“Sansa…” You stared into each other’s eyes for a moment longer before you forced yourself to look away. If you could, you would stare at her all day; but the pit in your stomach, the lessons you were taught, it all told you that that want was wrong.

Turning away, you busied yourself with folding new blankets and old gowns. Your eyes wander to Sansa from time to time as she started to sort through old letters. The grey fabric stained with House Stark colors started to turn darker and with shades of blue mixed in as you sifted through Sansa’s new dresses. The colors of House Arryn, where Littlefinger had stowed her away for safe keeping. The thought of the man alone made you shiver in disgust.

“Lord Baelish has placed himself in a great position, by your side.”

“Has he?” Sansa asked, not looking up from her letters.

“Indeed,” you continued, “you and Jon hold the power in the North now. I fear that he might try to-”

“Worry not, Y/N. I don’t trust him either. If there is one thing I learned in King’s Landing it is that you can trust no one.” You frowned at her harsh words.

“Except for family?” Sansa turned then, blue eyes bright.

“Except for family.” She bit her lower lip for a moment, suppressing a smile before she added, “you almost sounded jealous.” She stepped towards you, her eyes darkening with desire. The pit in your stomach grew and you swallowed hard. You had missed her so much.

“Sansa, my feelings…they always lied with you even when-”

A knock at the door disrupted your words that tumbled from your lips. Sansa torn her gaze away and moved towards the door. When she opened it, you took note of the panicked messenger that was breathing heavily. Sansa cocked her head at him.

“What is it?”

“Lady Stark, it’s your brother-”

“What has Jon done now?”

“Not Lord Snow, mi’lady, Lord Brandon Stark has returned!” Sansa turned to glance at you, her wide eyes meeting your own. Without another word, the girl rushed out the door and you followed swiftly behind. When you made your way outside, slightly short of breath, a crowd had gathered around a large cart.

Sansa stood before it, staring at a brown haired boy who sat within it. It was Bran; older now, quiet with a blank expression on his features. He was no longer the boy you had grown alongside. None of the Stark children, those that had survived, were the same anymore.

Before you could get any closer, Sansa hugged her long-lost brother. He didn’t move to return the embrace, but the sight comforted you nonetheless. Sansa’s family was returning to her, piece by broken piece. It would take a while for her true self to return but you felt that one day it would. 

Family was Sansa’s heart; and one day, you hoped to see yourself in her family alongside her siblings. As she parted from her brother, Sansa gave you a soft, familiar smile that brought you back to your youth. Perhaps that day wasn’t too far off in the future.

Without another word, the girl rushed out the door and you followed swiftly behind. When you made your way outside, slightly short of breath, a crowd had gathered around a large cart.

Sansa stood before it, staring at a brown haired boy who sat within it. It was Bran; older now, quiet with a blank expression on his features. He was no longer the boy you had grown alongside. None of the Stark children, those that had survived, were the same anymore.

Before you could get any closer, Sansa hugged her long-lost brother. He didn’t move to return the embrace, but the sight comforted you nonetheless. Sansa’s family was returning to her, piece by broken piece. It would take a while for her true self to return but you felt that one day it would. 

Family was Sansa’s heart; and one day, you hoped to see yourself in her family alongside her siblings. As she parted from her brother, Sansa gave you a soft, familiar smile that brought you back to your youth. Perhaps that day wasn’t too far off in the future.
trail.content:
It had been a long while since there had been a servant of House Stark in Winterfell; let alone a true born Stark. Upon the return of Ned Stark’s eldest daughter, new life floods the old castle. Shared memories resurface and forgotten feelings arise once more. Perhaps there is hope for this broken, scattered family after all.

It was a sign, a message from the Old Gods that the tides of fortune were shifting. It had to be. The small flakes that fell from the grey skies filled you with a sense of hope; one that, despite the horror surrounding you, could not be snuffed out. Finally, you thought, the fates would fall in the favor of House Stark once more. 

Days after the first signs of the coming winter started to lazily float down from the clouds, a more vivid display of change walked through the gates of Winterfell. It strode in, carried on the shoulders of a strong young woman with flowing red locks. Sansa Stark, Lady Stark now, had finally returned. Alongside her half-brother, Jon Snow. While her homecoming spark much join amongst those in the North, you couldn’t help but feel that undying bud of hope wither slightly.

For while Sansa Stark was a source of new hope, she was a source of bittersweet feelings for you. Having grown up along the Stark siblings, you formed a tight connection with the girl; one that was not shared in the way you longed for it to be. Dreams of holding her fell short when she talked about how she fancied the dear Prince Joffrey.

Time had passed now, and perhaps her heart had changed along with it. You wished that the glimmer of hope you held applied to that as well as you walked up to the main castle gates. The two guards stationed there looked you up and down, glaring at you stepped forwards.

“I’m Y/N L/N, my family has been serving the member of House Stark for centuries. I am here to take up my position as handmaiden to the Lady of the House.” One of the guards scoffed at your words, shaking his head at the other.

“Look here, peasant, Lady Stark gave us strict orders to-”

“Let my family enter without questioning. Yet it seems you have failed to complete this task.” Shocked and wide-eyed, the guard turned to face Sansa. She stood stoically, a dark furred cloak graced her slim shoulders. Familiarly piercing blue eyes stared daggers into the bumbling men before you. With a slight smile on your lips you stepped past the guards as they apologized for the inconvenience.

“Y/N,” Sansa said, her gaze softening as it shifted to you, “it has been too long.”

“Indeed it has, my Lady.”

“Sansa. You may always call me Sansa.” She waved off your formalities, lifting you from your bowing posture as a true leader would. Heat rose to your cheeks as you met her icy stare once more. She had changed, something deep within her had shifted, but she was still as bossy as she had been in your youth.

“I’ve missed you, Sansa,” you said, straightening your back. “I dreamed of the day you would return.”

“As did I,” Sansa replied, a sigh escaping her lips as she spoke. She glanced around the stone-brick walls of her home, as if comparing it to the memory she had so dearly clung to in King’s Landing. “Come now, I’ve taken up my Lord Father and Lady Mother’s chambers. There is much to sift through and clean.”

The walk through the silent halls of Winterfell was just that; deathly quiet. Even with the new vigor felt by the Northerns on their leader’s heirs return, the halls of their home were still with loss. As you followed Sansa, you passed doorways to old rooms. One was Robb’s, the boy King who treated you with kindness when you talked of Sansa. Another to the right was Rickon’s. The poor boy never stood a chance against the harsh world around him. Then Bran’s room, then Arya’s, both empty and devoid of life.

“I think about them, always,” Sansa murmurs as she unlocks the door to the chambers that her parents once lived in. “I see them in my dreams. Happy and alive.”

“There are ways to be happy again, Sansa.” You rest a hand on her cloaked shoulder and the girl turns her Tully blue eyes to you. She studies your face a moment longer before pushing the door before her open.

“Perhaps….”

At soon as the door opened, you both strode inside. A flood of warm memories rushed back to you. Ned Stark and Catelyn, raising their children, happy to raise you alongside them. You remember washing their fur blankets, being distracted by Sansa’s singing in the distance. Then the Boltons. They burned those same blankets, just as they scorched the fields of the North. You remembered running for your life after your family had been killed.

An alliance towards the Starks under the cruel rule of House Bolton was a death sentence. You had no choice but to leave your home behind. As much as it had pained you then, you were glad you did. If you hadn’t, you wouldn’t have been reunited with Sansa.

“Do you remember the day that Rickon was born?” You turned at Sansa’s question, brows furrowed slightly.

“Of course,” you replied, watching as she sat on her parent’s old bed. “You were so worried by your mother’s cries that you had me take you to the Godswood to pray.”

“Yes, and I had you pray beside me.” You nodded at the memory. “Did you pray?”

“What do you mean?”

“When my family was being torn apart by the lions, did you pray?” Her words hung in the air between you. Such sadness fell from her words and your heart broke.

“I did, Sansa. Every night I would pray that Robb would win each battle he fought. I prayed that we would find Arya. I prayed that I would see you once more before the life left my eyes forever. It seems the Gods have answered my prayers, for here you are.” You moved as you spoke, standing in front of Sansa. In a fit of passion you ran your fingers through the strands of auburn hair that fell around her face.

“I gave up praying,” Sansa whispered, “but when I did I wished for you to save me. Not my mother, not my father’s loyal men, not even Robb. Just you. I wanted…”

“Sansa…” You stared into each other’s eyes for a moment longer before you forced yourself to look away. If you could, you would stare at her all day; but the pit in your stomach, the lessons you were taught, it all told you that that want was wrong.

Turning away, you busied yourself with folding new blankets and old gowns. Your eyes wander to Sansa from time to time as she started to sort through old letters. The grey fabric stained with House Stark colors started to turn darker and with shades of blue mixed in as you sifted through Sansa’s new dresses. The colors of House Arryn, where Littlefinger had stowed her away for safe keeping. The thought of the man alone made you shiver in disgust.

“Lord Baelish has placed himself in a great position, by your side.”

“Has he?” Sansa asked, not looking up from her letters.

“Indeed,” you continued, “you and Jon hold the power in the North now. I fear that he might try to-”

“Worry not, Y/N. I don’t trust him either. If there is one thing I learned in King’s Landing it is that you can trust no one.” You frowned at her harsh words.

“Except for family?” Sansa turned then, blue eyes bright.

“Except for family.” She bit her lower lip for a moment, suppressing a smile before she added, “you almost sounded jealous.” She stepped towards you, her eyes darkening with desire. The pit in your stomach grew and you swallowed hard. You had missed her so much.

“Sansa, my feelings…they always lied with you even when-”

A knock at the door disrupted your words that tumbled from your lips. Sansa torn her gaze away and moved towards the door. When she opened it, you took note of the panicked messenger that was breathing heavily. Sansa cocked her head at him.

“What is it?”

“Lady Stark, it’s your brother-”

“What has Jon done now?”

“Not Lord Snow, mi’lady, Lord Brandon Stark has returned!” Sansa turned to glance at you, her wide eyes meeting your own. Without another word, the girl rushed out the door and you followed swiftly behind. When you made your way outside, slightly short of breath, a crowd had gathered around a large cart.

Sansa stood before it, staring at a brown haired boy who sat within it. It was Bran; older now, quiet with a blank expression on his features. He was no longer the boy you had grown alongside. None of the Stark children, those that had survived, were the same anymore.

Before you could get any closer, Sansa hugged her long-lost brother. He didn’t move to return the embrace, but the sight comforted you nonetheless. Sansa’s family was returning to her, piece by broken piece. It would take a while for her true self to return but you felt that one day it would. 

Family was Sansa’s heart; and one day, you hoped to see yourself in her family alongside her siblings. As she parted from her brother, Sansa gave you a soft, familiar smile that brought you back to your youth. Perhaps that day wasn’t too far off in the future.

summary: “She’s not one of us” is what we said to the French when we kicked their imperialist ass out of our home. Therefore, the Starks...
body:
“She’s not one of us” is what we said to the French when we kicked their imperialist ass out of our home. Therefore, the Starks are the only ones allowed to celebrate 5 de Mayo.

I rest my case.

tags: thank you for ruining the magic isaac
summary: There’s nothing personal when Bran tells Theon, “You’re a good man.” What he’s basically doing there is that he knows that Arya...
text: There’s nothing personal when Bran tells Theon, “You’re a good man.” What he’s basically doing there is that he knows that Arya is running and charging on her way to save the day, and Bran recognizes that he needs to buy some more time. And that’s a real moment there where Theon could give up again, as we’ve seen him do several times before. He looks at the Night King like, is he just going to run away or give up? And Bran recognizes that Theon needs that final push to give it one last go, to buy enough time for Arya.
source: Isaac Hempstead Wright, The New York Times (May 2019)

summary: I swear I LOVE Bran SO much this season. I can't explain it, he just seems lowkey snarky and knows the shit people are up to and...
question: I swear I LOVE Bran SO much this season. I can't explain it, he just seems lowkey snarky and knows the shit people are up to and just lets it happen. He's a dramatic bitch and I absolutely am living for it. He hopped on my top 5 for this season.
answer: He has more scenes this season compared to s7 and the writers aren’t interested in shocking us with the change in Bran so we have conversations about his disability, purpose, interests, his knowledge of the Night King, etc. Plus the way he keeps trolling people is a classic

summary: He looked south, and saw the great blue-green rush of the Trident. He saw his father pleading with the king, his face etched...
body:
He looked south, and saw the great blue-green rush of the Trident. He saw his father pleading with the king, his face etched with grief. He saw Sansa crying herself to sleep at night, and he saw Arya watching in silence and holding her secrets hard in her heart. There were shadows all around them. One shadow was dark as ash, with the terrible face of a hound. Another was armored like the sun, golden and beautiful. Over them both loomed a giant in armor made of stone, but when he opened his visor, there was nothing inside but darkness and thick black blood.

He lifted his eyes and saw clear across the narrow sea, to the Free Cities and the green Dothraki sea and beyond, to Vaes Dothrak under its mountain, to the fabled lands of the Jade Sea, to Asshai by the Shadow, where dragons stirred beneath the sunrise.

Finally he looked north. He saw the Wall shining like blue crystal, and his bastard brother Jon sleeping alone in a cold bed, his skin growing pale and hard as the memory of all warmth fled from him. And he looked past the Wall, past endless forests cloaked in snow, past the frozen shore and the great blue-white rivers of ice and the dead plains where nothing grew or lived. North and north and north he looked, to the curtain of light at the end of the world, and then beyond that curtain. He looked deep into the heart of winter, and then he cried out, afraid, and the heat of his tears burned on his cheeks.

A Game of Thrones - Bran III

summary: Valar Morghulis - Unreal_Kitty - Game of Thrones (TV) [Archive of Our Own]
title: Valar Morghulis - Unreal_Kitty - Game of Thrones (TV) [Archive of Our Own]
excerpt: An Archive of Our Own, a project of the Organization for Transformative Works
description:
All men must die. Some fall for love, others for greed, and others still for nothing at all. What does Theon Greyjoy die for? A girl sees. A girl knows.

It takes time to die from a spear to the gut. Time enough for Theon to see what his sacrifice bought from the God of Death.

@atimefordirewolves This story was inspired by a post you made about how Theon died without realizing he succeeded in protecting Bran. The show may have let him die without that closure, but I certainly won’t.
